The Scotsman Hotel
8.6 Excellent
Based on 317 reviews

We were trying to decide between two hotels for our visit to Edinburgh for the last weekend of the Fringe Festival and Edinburgh Tattoo - their busiest time of the year.

When looking at the photos of the two hotels, the Scotsman appealed to us more than the other from the decor. But the decider was that one of my daughters who, as a young college student 6 years earlier had visited Edinburgh with a friend, recognized the hotel and restaurant as the one which had welcomed them so warmly one evening, despite their obviously not being big spenders and being tired and hungry! We couldn't have made a better choice and they still welcome you very warmly. The location is terrific. We could walk everywhere but the shipyard. It's a beautiful old hotel with updated features like a luxurious bed and bathroom. We were travelling with 2 of our daughters who are in their 20s. Our room was on two levels, with the bedroom and bathroom upstairs. We had a beautiful view of Edinburgh and the castle. The downstairs windows looked out towards Calton Hill. The bathroom was HUGE with an excellent rainhead shower. (We didn't use the lovely bathtub) Our daughters' room included a sauna off their bathroom! From the moment we pulled up in the car the staff went above and beyond. Ivor drove with me to the parking spot, which is close to the hotel but required going around the block in heavy traffic. To make sure I didn't get lost or frustrated, he drove with me and showed me how to get in to the hotel from the lower level. The staff are all exceptional. Ivor went above and beyond the whole time, but Nick and the other bellman were wonderful too. The staff in the restaurant very accommodating and pleasant. We got to walk through the lobby of other hotel we had been considering and all of us agreed that we had picked the better hotel. We love the tartan fabrics (from Anta) on the wing chairs in the reception area and wood paneling. There are little reminders that this once house

Show more
Cheryl , United Kingdom
The Principal Edinburgh George Street
8.5 Excellent
Based on 349 reviews

My son and I came to Edinburgh to find him a flat so we chose a central location. Parking is a NIGHTMARE and this was not properly explained to us.

Consequently, we spent disproportionate time hunting for parking. The hotel staff are great. Friendly and attentive. Our room was a dreadful room badly needing updating. This should have been explained to us, prior to booking it. On Sunday morning we had to come down for breakfast twice. Our first visit was 9.30 am. There were massive queues waiting to be seated. We were told it would only take a few minutes to resolve. We returned at 10.00am to a BIGGER queue. We joined the queue at 10.20 and were seated at 10.45. Breakfast ends at 11.00am. The breakfast was incomplete ( no sausage, no bacon, greasy eggs etc). Again we had to wait. The quality of the food was poor. The sausage in particular was tasteless. I asked for freshly cooked eggs as the ones I had were cold. This is supposed to be a 4 star hotel. NOT impressed. I have conveyed these same thoughts to the hotel management. They have responded saying they know of these problems and are to resolve them in the future. In my opinion they should not be booking up the hotel if they cannot cope with the volume. The hotel has offered me a free upgrade and free breakfast. I will not be staying there again.

Show more
Tom , United Kingdom
Old Town Chambers
9.2 Exceptional
Based on 300 reviews

This was one of the most beautiful hotel rooms we've ever stayed in - luxurious, spacious and well laid-out.

We booked a one-bedroom family apartment and our 8-year-old was so thrilled to find that she had a separate 'secret cubby hole' with her own double bed. Small touches like the nespresso machine, huge smart tv, divine toiletries and state of the art microwave and oven really made our stay almost perfect. Only cons were the steps needed to make our way here - we realized that many of the reviews really down played the getting there part. We took the 'easier' way going up Cockburn Street from the train station, and still it was a steep slope. We looked at the 100 steps of the much faster route and reckoned we wouldn't be able to make it up that way although we did return via that much shorter route. Our room was also extremely noisy at night as it faced a major stairway. Spoilt lights in the room were also never replaced as were the nespresso capsules. But still, perfect stay!

Show more
Katherine , Singapore
The Knight Residence by Mansley Serviced Apartments
9.2 Exceptional
Based on 116 reviews

We enjoyed our stay at Knights Residence at the beginning of our trip to Scotland. The hotel has a convenient and reasonably priced car park, very helpful for us since we had a car in order to visit other parts of the country later in the trip.

We received a very warm welcome from Chris, the manager on duty. The hotel provides some basics on arrival - bread, milk, tea, coffee - very thoughtful! Tesco is around the corner. The unit had a nice apartment style layout, with a nice assortment of entertainment and full kitchen (the reason for my 5 rating). The location is very convenient, there are good restaurants nearby, and it's an easy walk to get to Edinburg Castle. All in all this hotel is a good value, the rooms are impeccably clean and the location is convenient. We stayed on a Friday and Saturday night, on Friday night the neighborhood was noisy due to some nearby bars, this was the only negative. I highly recommend Knights Residence and would stay again.

Show more
Peter , United States
Dalmahoy Hotel and Country Club
8.8 Excellent
Based on 71 reviews

This hotel is a wedding factory. Priority seems to be weddings - hotel is set up to cater for large wedding parties at the detriment of affecting other guests.

I could not get reliable service from many areas of the hotel - staff seem inexperienced or just lacking in good customer service skills. The first morning at breakfast - someone could be heard screaming and yelling at their staff in the kitchen, from the Dining room. I saw a member of staff drop cutlery on the floor and then proceed to put it back in a clean cutlery drawer. I asked for tea outside on the patio - which came with a cup covered in lipstick! As i sat drinking my tea taking in the beautiful view of the golf course (that my husband was playing on) i was asked to move elsewhere to accommodate a wedding party that had taken over the bar/lounge area (closed to other hotel guests for 2 hours). We had to go to the leisure centre bar/grill for lunch as the main bar was closed for a wedding reception. We ordered food at the leisure centre bar and then had to wait 45 mins for a poached egg on toast and cheese sandwich (????). My husband ended up carrying his sandwich out to the golf course so as not to miss his tee off time (which we had advised the bar/brasserie of as we sat down). I could go on but this probably sums up our experience - disappointing, not relaxing and no point booking here for a relaxing couples weekend as its full of wedding guests. The main hotel decor is tired and its not value for money at £250 a night. Such a beautiful setting but everything else lets it down - in need of some good management.

Show more
Helen , United Kingdom
Cityroomz Edinburgh Hotel
8.1 Excellent
Based on 197 reviews

The hotel was spacious, clean, and in good condition. I didn't try the breakfast so I don't know if it was good or not.

This hotel is in a great location on Princes Street in New Town!! Easy walk to everything: shops, restaurants, Old Town... Only weird thing (to me) is that they don't have phones in the rooms. They told me it's because they're a budget hotel, but the other budget hotels I stayed at elsewhere in Europe all had a phone in the room. The other downside is that only one of the two windows opened, and only partially. I can imagine it getting hot in warm weather. The room did have a good quality fan, which I made use of in the mornings, as the steam from the shower can make the room humid. Random tip: there's a Starbucks across the street, but if you have a taste for an evening latte be warned, they close early! 6:30 or 7:30pm depending on the day.

Show more
Aimee , Canada
The Place
7.9 Very good
Based on 69 reviews

The staff were exceptionally helpful; we had arrived early that morning, and they were extremely accommodating in holding our luggage, getting the room ready ahead of time, and making us comfortable in the interim.

The room itself was very comfortable; I found the decor and lighting fixtures unconventional, but not unpleasantly so. Additionally, they offered complimentary wifi for guests, which had been unheard of in our travels in the UK up to that point (and this was 5 hotels into our trip). I can provide only two slight negatives. The first is not actually the hotel's fault; the street in front of the hotel is currently undergoing major construction and is therefore closed...so getting to the hotel involves a bit of a walk from the nearest taxi drop point (which is around the corner, around half a block or so). This is not a slight against them; however, if you're in a wheelchair, it could represent a problem. Which brings me to the second (related) item: the rooms are accessible solely via staircase, which could prove prohibitive to those with physical handicaps. Overall, we had a great experience here, and I would strongly recommend this hotel.

Show more
Jesse , United States
Fraser Suites Edinburgh Hotel
8.7 Excellent
Based on 347 reviews

Attractive luxury hotel with well appointed rooms, but multiple problems detracted from our experience.

Shelving was missing from a clothes cupboard, bathroom door tended to stick when closed, a sliding door could not be moved except with strenuous effort, and shower controls jammed on our last day (thankfully in the off position). We were told there will be an air conditioning system installed this summer, but without it our room was uncomfortably hot two days, and we did not want to open our window because it looked out on a noisy construction site behind the hotel. There is a self-serve laundry room which was very convenient, but the dryer did not work, perhaps because of blocked venting, leaving us with hot, wet clothes to dry by hanging them in our bathroom. The lift was out of service for several days. This problem was fixed by the time we left, and mitigated somewhat because the hotel is on the side of a steep hill, so no room is more than 4 floors from the street entrance which is on the third floor. Staff was attentive and anxious to please so I expect these problems will all be ironed out eventually.

Show more
Howard , Canada
The Principal Edinburgh Charlotte Square
8.9 Excellent
Based on 80 reviews

As you can tell from the title, I wanted comfort and a bit of fine luxe. Was in Edinburgh for a lecture and book festival and it was fantastic that Roxburghe was right in front of it.

Loved the bathrobe and sophistication of bedroom layout. I had the 2 most relaxing nights ever at this place. Room service was delish though there is a tray charge for this - tipping I guess! Would def come back again to try out the spa and use the steam room. A lovely home away from home, in one of the most magically mesmerising cities in the UK. Do it!

Show more
Davina , Singapore
Ten Hill Place, BW Premier Collection
8.6 Excellent
Based on 125 reviews

Great! Simply Great for an affordable price! Hotel management knows their differences compared to other city hotels, and they are trying their best to cover up those differences.

The room was wonderful with all the amenities provided with regard to its price. Layout of the room was good too, not too narrow, and the wide bathroom. Also the view from the windows was open and freshing. Making you feel that you are in Edinburgh. Good Wi-Fi as well. Breakfast is same in every and each hotel, traditional scottish. Lifts were reliable and quick. It might seem a little further up the city centre compared to others but actually just 7 mins walk and we were on The mile end. Car parking is limited, but the street is available until 8:30 in the mornings. Only few stains in the bathtub is the negative thing we could say. The toileteries were wonderful btw. I wouldn't think for a minute if I 'd go to Edinburgh again.

Show more
Cem , Turkey
The Balmoral Hotel
9.2 Exceptional
Based on 47 reviews

Very pleasant but just didn't have that all important wow factor. No tea/coffee facilities in the room , one calls down to reception and within 5 minutes they arrive.

But a rather tacky white plastic kettle accompanied by various tea and coffee sachets, you cannot be serious. Has to be nespresso or similar in this type of establishment. Breakfast way overpriced at £25 per head, with the usual breakfast buffet free for all as it was very busy. Not a great start to your day especially as my wife had a couple of yoghurts ,coffee and water!!! Compared to the pre theatre menu we enjoyed the night before , breakfast was a let down. Valet parking excellent, Staff excellent , especially those in the spa and at the door.

Show more
david , United Kingdom
Aparthotel Adagio Edinburgh Royal Mile
8 Very good
Based on 19 reviews

Haymarket Hub Hotel
7.9 Very good
Based on 461 reviews

Opinion is pretty divided on this hotel, but I think it's pretty typical of all Tune hotels around the world.

I'll list down some of the features of the hotel and you guys can decide for yourself. I have to say that many of these points are 'neutral', so it's really depends on the type of traveller you are. 1. Location - yes it's near the Haymarket station and very convenient for travelling by train. It doesn't take any effort to find at all, the hotel is literally across the street. A negative point though is that the hotel is a good 15-20 min walk from the main city attractions. Options for getting into the main tourist area are by tram, train or walking. The first two obviously cost $$ so if you're on a budget clearly this is not great, and walking is totally fine on a good weather day. It's quite a pleasant walk through the gardens but I would think it's a pain during winter months though. Brr! 2. Extras and room size - Yes, the room is small. But this is to be expected and the hotel doesn't hide this. It is a budget hotel after all. A little warning about the extras: you have to pay for every single thing, including towels, tv and wireless. Storing luggage while waiting for check in at 3pm will also set you back £2.50/bag (!!!) Point is, it's completely fine if you can live without these 'basics' - bring your own towel and use the WiFis in cafes. Personally though, I think the Tune Group may want to rethink its strategy on this. It works on the basis of pay for what you use similar to budget airlines, but flying short distance is completely different from staying in a place. Technically, not providing any of these basics makes Tune Hotels more like a hostel, but with even less facilities than a hostel and at a higher cost. This doesn't make this particular hotel a bad one though, but you just have to go in with your eyes open, although if you book through online sites the prices for these 'extras' are already included in the price so you won't notice it. Com

Show more
Xiuhua , Singapore
Britannia Hotel Edinburgh
6.3 Good
Based on 159 reviews

I have been staying at Britannia hotels for many years and they have always been a favourite. However, the experience that my friend and I witnessed was not good.

Noisy guests who took over the entire dining area, very loud behaviour. Could not get into the room , swipe card not working. No cups in the room to make a coffee. Noise levels young people banging on doors and screaming, very scary as situation. Upon leaving we spoke to the male receptionist to let him know what had happened. Baring In mind this was the second time we had informed him of the situation. He displayed a face , didn't care attitude. I kindly asked home to call a taxi- 30 mins later no taxi. Went back into the hotel and the other male receptionist stated that no taxi was ordered. After another 10 minutes the taxi came. The taxi man knew the male receptionist rather large man who says that the hotel reception never answer phone and often leave guests outside waiting for taxis unnecessary. Overall a horrible experience that could have been solved.

Show more
Rosie , United Kingdom
Albany Ballantrae Hotel
8 Very good
Based on 86 reviews

We booked the hotel for a romantic time in. The hotel is centrally located, just few streets away from Princess St.

After reading the reviews we decided to book this hotel for the weekend without thinking that anything could be wrong as the room price was 150 pounds per night. We were taught otherwise. The hotel is advertised as a 4 star boutique hotel. The common areas were dirty and run down. The room itself needed repairs. Damp on walls is visible in bathrooms (we stayed at 2 different rooms and both had a similar appearance). The decor was dated and the TV in one of the rooms did not work. The breakfast was continental which is fine as long as it offers a good choice of bakery products, a good selection of cheeses, ham and spreads. The only choice which we were given were long life croissants, one type of ham and two types of cheese presented without imagination. Additionally, cereals, coffee, tee etc were available along some fruit. A rather boring selection for a 4 star hotel! On a positive note, the room itself was clean, which we very much appreciated. We have traveled the world, have staid in 5 star luxury hotels as well as in shacks on the beach, in budget hotels and minus 5 star hotels in Myamar or Cambodia. There, at least we knew what we are signing up for. In the case of the Albany Ballantrae Hotel, we did not receive either a room or service we paid for. We expected something far more romantic and at standard of a 4 star hotel as advertised.

Show more
przemyslaw , Germany
G and V Royal Mile
9.2 Exceptional
Based on 119 reviews

We were keen to try the Missoni having watched it being built whilst we were living in Edinburgh. Having now moved away, we took the opportunity for a short trip in December 2009 and managed to get a two night stay via Agoda.

It's the cheapest price, so there does not appear to be much discounting going on. We checked in at noon to find we could get straight in to our room; the staff said the hotel was pretty quiet that day. The rooms were a pretty standard size, adequate but well laid out with a King size bed, armchair, desk chair and a sliding mirror wardrobe/shelving set up. Stylish decor and very comfortable, with a multi-function tv and wireless internet. (Great selection of free movies available, with some very up to date titles; we could have stayed in and watched loads!) Excellent coffee machine and a complimentary mini bar with water, beer and soft drinks (a refreshing change from the usual overpriced offerings). I also took advantage of the complimentary laundry service (2 items per day) and found them returned promptly and well pressed. Ordered room service on the first night, which was ok, but nothing spectacular, however it did turn up quickly, hot and nicely presented. Bathroom great, with large walk in shower, bathrobes and slippers, great toiletries and good towels. Excellent magnifying mirror too. We didn't eat in the restaurant, but had a couple of drinks in the bar; usual hotel prices but the cocktails I had were very good and the service was very friendly and quick. Checkout was efficient, the bill was correct and we were offered storage for our bags until later that day. All in all, we would be very happy to stay here again whenever we can find an excuse to visit Edinburgh!

Show more
Karen , United Kingdom
Radisson Blu Edinburgh
8.7 Excellent
Based on 89 reviews

Perfect. We were in Edinburgh as a stop off between the airport and a wedding venue and also for the hen party.

The hotel was super close to restaurants, bars, shops, everything. The staff were very helpful, as me and my partner were arriving at different times, they checked us in separately which meant we weren't constricted in the room waiting for each other. Rooms were clean, neat and we had a great view. Did not try the food, it looked delicious, but as with all hotels it is a little bit more expensive than it could be!

Show more
Chloe , United Kingdom
The Royal Scots Club Edinburgh
8.8 Excellent
Based on 66 reviews

We had an excellent stay at the Royal Scots Club, we had a beautiful family room & couldn't ask for anything better, 3 adults stayed (we were going to see a show in the Playhouse - which is within walking distance) & there was more than enough room for us all.

Breakfast was everything you could ask for & the staff were really friendly & helpful. The building itself is lovely & a bit different to a normal looking hotel, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend the Royal Scots Club & we are looking forward to going back the next time we are planning a trip through to Edinburgh..

Show more
Christina , United Kingdom
Leonardo Royal Hotel Edinburgh
7.9 Very good
Based on 21 reviews

Premier Inn advertise themselves as a budget hotel; they may very well be a budget hotel in everything except the price.

I do not consider £125 a night including breakfast to be budget prices. I stayed 3 nights and on te final day, I had to telephone reception at 4.15 to get my room made up. I had exactly the same problem on my previous stay at this hotel 2 years ago so this was not an isolated incident. The card you hang outside your door only asks for your room to be made up after 12.00 pm! I have stayed in many hotels of a similar standard and they are the only hotel chain to do this. There were problems with the lifts and whilst there was a notice to say that they were working to improve the lifts, there was no notice on a particular lift to say which one they were working on.

Show more
Alan , United Kingdom
The Dunstane Houses
8.9 Excellent
Based on 42 reviews

The anticipation generated from the initial view of a most impressive building facade was not deflated when we ascended the stairs and our room's door opened.

Period features and a sense of timeless elegance prevail. Service and friendliness are clearly the ethos of Dunstane. Our room was nicely appointed if not somewhat cosy. Can't be too critical of anything really. Bit of a walk to town but peace and quiet are the dividend. Be aware that there are no lifts and that some rooms are quite small but be comforted that beds are comfortable and there is plenty of parking. The included breakfast is excellent.

We stayed one night. Reservation was made through Agoda with full payment. At the time of check-in the reception we were asked whether we wanted breakfast if yes to pay in advance which we did.

On checking out were first asked to pay for accommodation once again. When told that we have already paid they had to go through several papers to find the payment, which they finally accepted. Then the reception asked to pay for breakfast which we promptly said had been paid on the previous night. Once again after going through several papers they accepted that we have paid for breakfast. The man at the counter was quite abrupt and grumpy and does not suit well to serve at the reception. We presume that the front desk has an accounting procedural issue when collating charges and I advise future travellers to check your bills carefully when checking out. It was quite embarrassing and the hotel did not offer any apology for their errors. We asked them to at least say sorry which they did quite reluctantly.

Ibis Edinburgh South Bridge Hotel
8.5 Excellent
Based on 137 reviews

Checking in was fast, the free wifi is working fine for normal browsing, the staffs were very helpful with directions when I asked for directions to Arthur's seat.

The rooms are clean and all the necessary items are provided (towels, shower gel, hair dryer, kettle). It would be better if there was one more rubbish bin in the room (there was only one bin in the toilet and none in the room). The bed was very comfortable and I had a very good sleep. The location of this hotel is perfect as I am looking to visit more of the historical side of Edinburgh. It is located nearby Royal Mile and the National Museum of Scotland is just one street away from the hotel. Few minutes walk from the Edinburgh Waverly station. There are lots of cafes and restaurants nearby. There is a Sainsbury's Local located right beside the hotel so it is super convenient for you to pick up some essential stuff like water. There is also a Costa beside the hotel and a Starbucks nearby (2 minutes walk). However there is one downside of the hotel which is the noise that the bar caused at night. I stayed at the top floor and it is still very loud so I could not imagine if I stayed at lower floors that are closer to the streets and the hotel bar. Definitely recommend higher floors if you intend to stay in this hotel. But I have to say it did not affect me much because I knocked out after a full day of exploring in the city.

7.8 Very good
Based on 168 reviews

I was staying in Edinburgh for the weekend to watch the Scotland v Italy rugby game and to visit family.

When I arrived at the hotel I was pleasantly suprised because although it is advertised as a 3.5* it appeared to be better than some 4* I'd stayed in. The check in was quick and effortless with a polite and friendly member of staff. Once I got to my room I was further pleased with how clean and warm it was - two of my most basic requirements for a hotel. There was a heater that could be adjusted to suit - a rarety in a lot of hotels i'm sad to say and the view of the city from the room was amazing. The bed was comfortable giving me a good nights sleep and in the morning I was refreshed with an excellent power shower. The room was small but that doesn't bother me, however 2 people I was travelling with upgraded their room to a larger one with a better view for a small supplement. I would also recommend having the afternoon tea in the restaurant, which is reasonably priced and left me feeling pleasantly satisfied . All in all I would definitely stay here again and strongly consider staying in a Mecure in other cities/countries if this is the set standard.

This is sadly one of the most underwhelming places I have stayed. It honestly seems like the owners have given up on it and are trying to milk every last penny out of it.

The staff are not friendly. your greeting is- sign this, you're in room ##. The house is old and creaky but not in a charming way. The bed is rock hard and creaks every time you roll over. It's not cheap either. The airport, the bus to the city from the airport, almost every pub, restaurant, hostel, coffee shop & hotel has free Wi-fi, but not this place. I'm sure I'm not alone in doing most of my trip planning online so it was incredibly frustrating. On top of that the overpriced wifi does not work in the rooms either.. It's also in the middle of nowhere. If you don't mind paying for taxi's everywhere it might be ok, but if you plan on walking, it's a 25 minute uphill walk to the edge of the city centre. This is a fairly cheap option but not cheap enough for a very average place.

Stayed here for 2 nights over the weekend and it was ideally located. Not too far from the centre, maybe around a 15 20 minute walk and also there are many local shops, takeaways and a Tesco express literally 1 minute away.

Check in was quick and the lady at check in gave us a map and gave us information on transport information to get to certain attractions if we didn't want to walk. The room was spacious and had a wardrobe for our clothes which also has a safe inside it. A nice big mirror with a chair and table. Kettle, cups, tea, coffee, biscuits and even bottled water. For the price we paid which was £120 for 2 nights for a weekend I doubt you will find anything better and as close to the centre. Would definitely stay here again and would recommend this hotel to anyone who is thinking of visiting Edinburgh. Anyone driving to the hotel may want to know that there's limited public parking spaces right outside. It is free after 6:30pm and Sundays are free.

8.2 Excellent

I have stayed in this Haymarket area of the city before and indeed several times on this street and must say was impressed with what encountered here.

The public areas are a nice mix of modern yet keeping the old character elements and even has an in house stylish bar area which I would image is open on request or at busier times. The room I stayed in was simple and stylish in layout, with whatever would need for a stay. Bed was comfy and ensuite albeit like many in city was small, were both more than adequate and clean which is the important factor. For the size of ensuite the internal space in the shower was actually very good and the shower was powerful and again spotless. Everyone encountered were pleasant and professional without being intrusive which can sometimes be the case in small guesthouse / hotels. I had a front street facing room and had no problems with noise and shutters on window kept light out perfect. Extra heater in room too which is good now the wintery weather here and means can control the heat of room to suit you. Also obviously beside Haymarket train station and has some great places to eat and drink a 5-10 min walk from door, including a great gin bar and an unassuming but fantastic Thai restaurant. Very happy with my 2 night stay and if prices were to be as competitive as were this time would not hesitate to stay again as it is a great base for in and out of airport.

The Location is satisfactory. You are a 15 min walk away from Prince's Street and the nearest of the city center, and 45 min away from the furthest of the city center.

The area is residential and quiet, but down the street you have a main street from Prince's Street to the Haymarket, where you have pubs, shops, smaller, cheaper restaurants as well as nicer ones. If you like to spend the night out partying, be ready for a ~40 min walk to the most active part of the town. On the other hand, the Hostel is situated 10 mins away from the beautiful and peaceful Water of Leith, which would be a highlight for those who want to enjoy a quiet afternoon in this small pocket of nature inside the city. So +1 to the location thanks to this. The Hostel has its own bar on the floor ground, common facilities downstairs and rooms and bathrooms upstairs. The bar is open to all with average to slightly above average prices (including your resident discount). That area is extremely nice and clean, and on some nights the bar is a nice plce to hang out peacefully, on some others there are activities planned (live music, quizzes...). The common facilities and room on the other hand are only cleaned once a week, on monday. A lot of people using only a couple stalls, the bathroom can be pretty unclean. They have suffered quite a lot from the use as well. The kitchen is okay-ish clean, although I believe the rules regarding cleaning and dishwashing should be better enforced. The bed linens were not all really clean. The common room ("backpacker's lounge") is not great (a couple tables, a tv, a computer), but there is a nice small, quiet (again, residential area), garden with a couple tables. On the other hand, the kitchen is pretty cool with a variety of utensils (although most are in poor condition), and you have access to various plugs and lockers. The staff was for the most part extremely friendly and helpful. All in all, recommended for someone solo traveling or in couple looking for

CityLivein

I would only stay here again if I didn't have a choice of something else. I'll just break this down into good and bad.

Good: Really well designed studio apartments, even though they are tiny, the design is excellent and makes them very comfortable to stay in. The location is great, only 15 mins walk to old town, 30 mins walk to the centre of things, plenty of buses, plenty of food options. The staff are very friendly and helpful. Bad: While on first glance the rooms look clean it only takes a day or two to realise, the cleaning is below standard. There are little areas that while don't need to be cleaned all the time, have clearly never been cleaned (a years worth of dust on a shelf, scum building up in corners of the shower and under the rim of the toilet). I met the cleaners, really nice people, just may need a bit of training. They only give one key per room, this was a real hassle for us. This meant on a couple of occasions I have had random people knocking on my door thinking it was their room. Once this was scary as it was 10pm and it was a middle aged drunk man, and once it was annoying as it was 1.30am. Lucky there a peep hole for security. The rooms are sound proof between them but not into the hall way. If anyone talks, walks or closes a door in the hallway, you will hear it. There are often parties in this building so this can be problematic with noisy groups coming walking the hallway at all times of night. The building has these insanely annoying elevators with an electronic voice. Because the sound proofing into the hallway is not good you can hear this elevator while lying in bed trying to sleep (more of a problem for light sleepers). The bed is very uncomfortable you can feel the springs. We used the duvet as a mattress cover and this solved the problem.

Booked this apartment for a birthday celebration in Edinburgh. With 3 travellers it was difficult to work out the best way to sort out our accommodation - a triple hotel room? three singles? so we looked at apartments and found this for the same price as a hotel.

More about Edinburgh

Edinburgh is easily one of the most beautiful cities in Europe. It beguiles visitors with an intoxicating blend of the old and new world and follows through with myriad commercial and cultural attractions. Standing at the threshold of it all is Edinburgh Airport, ushering visitors in from around the world.

Crowning the Old Town is Edinburgh Castle, an emblematic fortress with 1,000 years of history behind it. The entire historic quarter splays under it in a maze of cathedrals, stony architecture, and parliament buildings. Visitors can walk the Royal Mile from the castle to Holyrood Palace for the quintessential Edinburgh experience.

Across the valley from the Old Town is the New Town - a misleading title as the area has a few hundred years of history and its own UNESCO recognition. Characterized by late Georgian architecture, tidy streets, and leafy parks, the New Town has more commercial offerings.

Edinburgh receives a varied lot of tourists, and it excels at catering to mixed budgets and tastes. There are hotels near Edinburgh to suit everyone, spanning hostels and backpacker haunts to full-service luxury hotels.

Be sure to check out the interactive map of Edinburgh for information on hotel locations, attractions, and must-see destinations.

When looking at the photos of the two hotels, the Scotsman appealed to us more than the other from the decor. But the decider was that one of my daughters who, as a young college student 6 years earlier had visited Edinburgh with a friend, recognized the hotel and restaurant as the one which had welcomed them so warmly one evening, despite their obviously not being big spenders and being tired and hungry! We couldn't have made a better choice and they still welcome you very warmly. The location is terrific. We could walk everywhere but the shipyard. It's a beautiful old hotel with updated features like a luxurious bed and bathroom. We were travelling with 2 of our daughters who are in their 20s. Our room was on two levels, with the bedroom and bathroom upstairs. We had a beautiful view of Edinburgh and the castle. The downstairs windows looked out towards Calton Hill. The bathroom was HUGE with an excellent rainhead shower. (We didn't use the lovely bathtub) Our daughters' room included a sauna off their bathroom! From the moment we pulled up in the car the staff went above and beyond. Ivor drove with me to the parking spot, which is close to the hotel but required going around the block in heavy traffic. To make sure I didn't get lost or frustrated, he drove with me and showed me how to get in to the hotel from the lower level. The staff are all exceptional. Ivor went above and beyond the whole time, but Nick and the other bellman were wonderful too. The staff in the restaurant very accommodating and pleasant. We got to walk through the lobby of other hotel we had been considering and all of us agreed that we had picked the better hotel. We love the tartan fabrics (from Anta) on the wing chairs in the reception area and wood paneling. I can provide only two slight negatives. The first is not actually the hotel's fault; the street in front of the hotel is currently undergoing major construction and is therefore closed...so getting to the hotel involves a bit of a walk from the nearest taxi drop point (which is around the corner, around half a block or so). This is not a slight against them; however, if you're in a wheelchair, it could represent a problem. Which brings me to the second (related) item: the rooms are accessible solely via staircase, which could prove prohibitive to those with physical handicaps. Show more david , United Kingdom Aparthotel Adagio Edinburgh Royal Mile 8 Very good Based on 19 reviews Haymarket Hub Hotel 7.9 Very good Based on 461 reviews Opinion is pretty divided on this hotel, but I think it's pretty typical of all Tune hotels around the world. I'll list down some of the features of the hotel and you guys can decide for yourself. I have to say that many of these points are 'neutral', so it's really depends on the type of traveller you are. 1. Location - yes it's near the Haymarket station and very convenient for travelling by train. It doesn't take any effort to find at all, the hotel is literally across the street. A negative point though is that the hotel is a good 15-20 min walk from the main city attractions. Options for getting into the main tourist area are by tram, train or walking. The first two obviously cost $$ so if you're on a budget clearly this is not great, and walking is totally fine on a good weather day. It's quite a pleasant walk through the gardens but I would think it's a pain during winter months though. Brr! 2. Extras and room size - Yes, the room is small. But this is to be expected and the hotel doesn't hide this. It is a budget hotel after all. A little warning about the extras: you have to pay for every single thing, including towels, tv and wireless. Storing luggage while waiting for check in at 3pm will also set you back £2.50/bag (!!!) Point is, it's completely fine if you can live without these 'basics' - bring your own towel and use the WiFis in cafes. Personally though, I think the Tune Group may want to rethink its strategy on this. It beguiles visitors with an intoxicating blend of the old and new world and follows through with myriad commercial and cultural attractions. Standing at the threshold of it all is Edinburgh Airport , ushering visitors in from around the world. Crowning the Old Town is Edinburgh Castle , an emblematic fortress with 1,000 years of history behind it. The entire historic quarter splays under it in a maze of cathedrals, stony architecture, and parliament buildings. Visitors can walk the Royal Mile from the castle to Holyrood Palace for the quintessential Edinburgh experience. Across the valley from the Old Town is the New Town - a misleading title as the area has a few hundred years of history and its own UNESCO recognition. Characterized by late Georgian architecture, tidy streets, and leafy parks, the New Town has more commercial offerings. Edinburgh receives a varied lot of tourists, and it excels at catering to mixed budgets and tastes. There are hotels near Edinburgh to suit everyone, spanning hostels and backpacker haunts to full-service luxury hotels.
